s.text: As a result of the Star Wars deal, Galoob devoted more and more of its resources to that line, shifting money out of internal development, staking the company, in a sense, on this product whose existence depended utterly on staying in the good graces of Lucasfilm.
The problem for toy companies is that they need to design and manufacture the toys for a movie without having any sense of how popular that movie is going to be.
On the other hand, if the movie's popular and you don't have enough product on hand to take advantage of those few weeks when your toys are hot, you won't get the chance again.
On the other hand, if the movie's popular and you don't have enough product on hand to take advantage of those few weeks when your toys are hot, you won't get the chance again.
The result, of course, has been a flood of toys based on everything from comic books to Westerns.

As the incredible box-office numbers for the trilogy's re-release showed, there are millions upon millions of American children, born a decade or more after Luke Skywalker first appeared, who nonetheless see him as their hero.
